history.content:
I took CS 168 in Fall 2017, and loved it (despite my performance in it). Professor Shenker is an amazing lecturer, and I feel that internet architecture and networking is really difficult to learn well on your own time, and is pretty relevant in the software industry. The material covered in DS 100 can definitely be self-studied, and honestly, I feel that students either care too much about titles or overvalue how helpful a DS Minor can be when they are already a CS/EECS major (somewhat redundant). Maybe the DS major helps, but not really the minor if you are already CS/EECS just learn Python and SQL. In addition, you already took CS 186 and CS 189 which DS 100 is supposed to "prepare" you for. In my opinion, your skillset is already pretty good to explore careers in Data Science.

I'm a CS Peer Advisor, so feel free to stop by in front of HP Auditorium M/W 2-4 PM if you want to talk in person!

children.subject: I'm in it this semester and it is webcast. It also has mandatory attendance but for those that had conflicts, you had to fill out a form to inform the staff and instead of a participation grade, your final exam would just be weighted heavier.
Where did you get the information that C100 isn't broadcast? When I go to course captures, I can see the lectures for the Fall 2017 semester : https://coursecapture.berkeley.edu/stat-c100
I guess for background I should mention that the things I learned from the class are maybe more useful for software engineering than for data science, and my focus is heavily on the former.

I can't speak to DS100, so I can't make a recommendation one way or the other here, but personally, 168 was one of the best classes I took. Everything relating to networking is definitely important, useful, and taught very well, but I think Shenker's greatest strength is in commenting on why network architecture evolved the way it did, and stressing what the most significant design choices were along the way. Even if I never deal with anything directly related to the material in this class, it would still be one of the most influential classes to me solely for its discussions on modularity and design. Even if you have no interest in the content, I'd still recommend the class for the opportunity to learn from Shenker.

history.content: I will be entering my last semester at Berkeley in Fall 2018, and I will face a dilemma between taking DS100 vs. CS168 in Fall 2018 since they are both mandatory attendance (no webcast) courses. If I choose CS168 I will not be able to pick up a DS minor. I have already taken EECS127/161/162/170/184/186/188/189/194. Are there any recommendations between these two classes (and any others)?
history.subject: CS168 vs DS100
